content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would consider the expected payoff for both choices, R and B, to make my decision.

If I always pick R, I will get 45$ when they also pick R, but nothing when they pick B. This happens in half of the games (37.5 times on average due to 75 rounds). So, for choosing R, the total payoff would be $37.5 * 45 + 0 * (75 - 37.5) = $1687.5.

If I always pick B, I will get 20$ in each game when they also pick B, and 40$ when they pick R. This happens 37.5 times on average when they pick R (75 / 2 = 37.5 rounds) and 37.5 times on average when they pick B (since it's the same player, we can consider it as one round for each player's choice). So, for choosing B, the total payoff would be $37.5 * 40 + 20 * (75 - 37.5) = $1812.5.

Since the expected payoff is higher when I pick B, it would make sense for me to choose B for a higher average payoff over the 75 rounds.

So my choice would be {B} as a human player.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would still choose B since it has a higher expected payoff over the long run.

However, it is important to note that since both players are making the same choice in this scenario, there is a chance for one player to change their strategy and switch to R in future rounds to take advantage of the 45$ payout when their opponent picks B. This would require careful observation of the opponent's behavior over time.

In the next round, I will choose {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, faced with the possibility of earning 45$ by switching to R when my opponent chooses R, I would consider changing my strategy for that specific round. However, since I understand that the higher expected payoff still lies in choosing B over the long run, I would choose to continue with my previous strategy and pick {B} again.

In this scenario, I receive 40$ while my opponent gets nothing. It may seem tempting to switch strategies for future rounds when the opponent picks R, but sticking with my chosen strategy of B can help maximize overall earnings in the long run due to its higher expected payoff.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I will choose {B} again. In the next round, I will consider choosing {R} to try and earn the higher payout of 45$ when my opponent also chooses B. In summary, in the next round I will choose {R} to test the waters and possibly earn a higher payout if my opponent also switches strategies. However, it is important to keep an eye on the opponent's behavior over time and adjust strategies accordingly to maximize overall earnings.
